addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

3 fe
b
1590
. M
r
Bodeleye from
e Haghe./

page.lettertext:
fol.124r
May it please yo
r
good L. to advertise her
Ma
tie
that wheras in her letter to
e
General states
, and
in another to my self, there is mention made of a
former letter, wherein I should be willed, to propose
the self same mater to
e states, whiche hath bin
heere delivered by
S
r
John Norreis
, I have not
yet receaved
e forsaid letter, nor any other letter
to any suche effect. Yo
r
L. only in yo
r
last
of
e 30 of De
c
vouchesafed to declare, that her
Hig
nes
would gladly have
e use of her forces,
at
are out of
e 4 townes to serve a purpose by
sea, to
e aide of
e
F
r
King
in
Brittaine.
Whiche was so sette downe in general wordes
w
t
out any motion unto me, to have it proposed,
to
e states of
e contrey. Howe
e message is
accepted, because S
r
John Norreis will certifie
at large, I should but troble yo
r
L. to report it
againe. For mine owne particular, her Hig
nes
being pleased to take this course w
t
e contrey,
I will give him w
at
assistance I shall any way
be able. But otherwise I am still of that opinion
that I imparted unto yow
e 14 of
e last.
It is greatly to be doubted, lest the
newe contribution, whiche is almost accorded
for
e levie of 3000 foote, and 300 horse, will
com e to nothing. For I see by many tokens they
doe imagine already, that if
e forces of these
contreis shall be much more increased, her Ma
tie
will take it for a fitte opportunitie to lessen her
charges, in hope that as then
e w
t
drawing of her
subjectes will be voide of danger to their state.
fol.124v
The speeche is given out, that
e
states of Hol-
land
have already past their graunt, for
threescore thousand poundes sterling, for their
portion. They doe greatly dislike
e solicitation of
e Frenche, for
e imploiment
of these forces in Brittaine: and I stand in
doubt therupon, for
at in a maner they speake
it openly, that they will not contribut to the
Germaine levies. The states doe re-
solve, as I am told at this instant, to write
unto her Ma
tie
out of hand, and shortly after to
send some person of purpose, to dissuade her in
this mater. For I never see them for any thing
so farre out of temper. The partie of
Zeland,
w
ch
was
e discoverer of
at mater,
wherw
t
yo
r
L. is acquainted is come newly
to
e Hage, and hath bettered his ouverture w
t
a newe informac
o
n, w
ch
I will specifie in my
next. For my warning is so short, upon the de-
parture of this bearer, that I can not write at
suche length, as willingly I would. Howbeit to
the end it may be folowed w
t
good expediti
o
,
and proceeded in effectually, to her Hig
nes
content,
I trust yo
r
L. will allowe,
at I shall impart
e whole desseigne to S
r
John Norreis, and use
his advise for
e accomplishing of that, whiche
is to be inquired, or otherwise perfourmed by us
that are heere. The
Governo
r
of
Flushing
hath had somw
at
of late disclosed unto
him, whiche himself will signfie to yo
r
L.
fol.125r
about
e like exploit, upon
e self same place.
But
e plotte, as it seemeth, is yet but maimed
and unperfitte. I thought it not
impertinent to send yo
w
an extract heereinclosed
of a point or two, that I have noted in certaine
letters, w
ch
were lately intercepted by
e Garri-
son of
Berghen.
The speeche that is
heere, that
e
Empero
rs
Ambassado
rs
are at hand,
and that their peace is proposed w
t
pleasing con-
ditions, doth very muche amase
e discreter
sort among
e people. For though
e greater part
of
e chiefest persons of these Provinces, are no-
thing to be douted, yet because
e multitude is hu-
morous, and guided by no man, and is withall
very weary of these daily exactions, wherewith
eir warres must be maintened, it is greatly to
be feared, they will commit some soddaine folly,
from whiche they will not be reclamed by
any after persuasion. In w
ch
respect I could
have wished, as I have formerly signified, that
S
r
John Norreis had come hither in a fitter oppor-
tunitie. For although it be but
a
borowing of so
many men for a time, yet it will be understood
by
e commons of
e contrey, to be a plaine
revocation of her Ma
ties
forces.
And thus for
this p
nt
I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. Fe
b
3. 90.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
